summary: This is a court subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Amazon.com, Inc., commanding the company to appear and produce subscriber records, order history, billing/shipping information, and payment details for specific email identifiers associated with Ghislaine Maxwell from January 1, 1994, to January 1, 2005, as part of the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, for which Amazon is being subpoenaed to produce records linked to her email addresses.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signed the subpoena as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, authorizing the demand for records from Amazon.

connections.description: Strauss, as U.S. Attorney, is prosecuting Maxwell in the criminal case, as evidenced by the subpoena she signed to gather evidence.

events.title: Amazon subpoena appearance date
events.description: Amazon.com, Inc. is commanded to appear before the U.S. District Court in New York to testify and produce records related to Ghislaine Maxwell's email accounts.

events.title: Subpoena issued to Amazon
events.description: The subpoena is dated and signed by U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss, demanding Amazon produce records for Maxwell's email addresses from 1994 to 2005.

locations: 40 Foley Square, Courtroom 906, Borough of Manhattan, City of New York, New York
300 Deschutes Way SW, Suite 208 Tumwater, WA 98501 (Amazon's legal department address for service)
keyFacts: The subpoena targets Amazon for records linked to email addresses gmaxl@mindspring.com, gmax@mindspring.com, gmaxl@ellmax.com, and gmax@ellmax.com, suggesting these were used by Ghislaine Maxwell.
The requested records span from January 1, 1994, to January 1, 2005, covering a critical period in the Epstein-Maxwell timeline.
The subpoena is part of the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330), indicating ongoing evidence gathering by prosecutors in 2021.
Failure to comply would constitute contempt of court, subjecting Amazon to civil sanctions and criminal penalties.
The document reveals the U.S. Attorney's Office under Audrey Strauss was actively pursuing digital and financial evidence from major corporations like Amazon in the Maxwell prosecution.
